data.title: Develop : back ported changes to DynamicVertexBuffer and VertexBuffer...
data.body: ... to get ParticleSample to at least build.

data.title: More sound fixes
data.body:
Hey there,
1: A simple IsContentLost property for RenderTarget2D because it needs to exist. I noticed that content doesn't seem to get lost in MonoGame, so "return false;" should be enough
2: A simple event-system for the OpenAL sound controller, so the SoundEffectInstance and therefore the Song and therefore the MediaPlayer and therefore the user can handle a MediaStateChanged event.
Without that, managing background music in a game is almost impossible and it also allows for MediaPlayers IsRepeating property to do anything useful.
Anyway, I'm not sure if this is completely WinRT compatible (see the Song constructor). Only some parts of the OpenAL sound stuff seem to be #if'd out for WinRT, so I'm not sure what applies here.
Let me know if something should be changed.

EDIT: uh.. sorry for the wrong indentation. I've set up my IDE to use spaces because that seems to be used most in MonoGame. But the OpenAL sound stuff seems to use tabs. Should I fix that?

data.title: Fixed some sound issues
data.body:
Hey there,
1: This will make the MGSongProcessor produce .wav songs when compiling content for Linux (because that's the only thing that's supported)
2: It fixes a problem when using the SoundEffect.Play() method with 3 parameters. The pitch was forwarded to openAL as is. However, a mapping from XNA's pitch to OpenAL's pitch should happen here.
I hope I diddn't forget to change any default values from 1 to 0.

data.title: Fixed Quaternion.ToMatrix calculation to be like the formula referenced.
data.body: The last four elements of the matrix weren't calculated correctly. There were identical to the 3rd group of elements.

data.title: Develop3d - various fixes, mostly Android related.
data.body:
See commits for self explanatory code. 

Probably the least obvious one is "Support loading non-xnb textures from models (BasicEffectReader etc)". I was having trouble getting alpha to work with my DXT compressed textures on Android, so I figured I'd just replace them with PNGs. This change allows you to do this as BasicEffectReader asks for a type T==Texture but we were only doing path normalization on type T==Texture2D when no XNB file is found.

data.title: Game Center Authentication Does Not Work
The past, the present and the future.
data.body:
We've all been witnessing this for a while now. With the Windows 8 scheduled for release and no comments regarding XNA from the current XNA developers can we be sure about future Microsoft involvement in this framework? Shawn porting various XNA aspects to the native DirectX SDK (of course, after being moved away from the froject: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2012/06/18/directx-tool-kit-is-now-on-codeplex.aspx) and no hearings on other developers blogs makes me a little bit worried. I don't think XNA's future is sure since it wouldn't be the first time Microsoft makes some of their projects slowly fading away from public eye.

And MonoGame's been here for a while now. Slowly growing and buggy at the beginning, but there are at least a few commits daily and even the bigger developers are using it when porting their games to mobile platforms now. You are growing fast. But what are your current sights on the future of the project? Are you just going to incorporate more and more XNA's features and making it available on as many platforms as you can or are you going to reach even further?

You see, MonoGame is now in very convenient position. Microsoft sponsored creation of kinda revolutionary piece of software (things like advanced shader creation or  _the amazing_ content pipeline weren't available for the average indie developer before XNA's came out, even the most simple-but-annoying things like game timing or modular extensions got so incredibly easy to manage) and gave it away for free. And you (the MonoGame team, that is) are, as the open source community does and should do, making it even more free, may I borrow from Richard Stallman, free as in freedom. Knowledge and thoughts that were put into one single piece of software is being adapted by community. It is a lot of responsibility in case Microsoft abandons XNA, because all the existing XNA's developers would shift to MonoGame.
And what happens when they do? Is MonoGame going to give they the same feeling of safety and support as XNA did? Will MonoGame be a stable, production-ready and developing game framework as XNA was?

In this fin de siecle of managed game programming, where the XNA was (I hope it still is and will be) the standing ground for many talented programmers, (just look at the people involved in this project and the games that were created with both XNA and MonoGame, Bastion being my favorite) are you going to stand right where you are now and continue with the MonoGame project?

data.title: Develop3d

data.title: FixedTimeStep/VSync improvements
data.body:
Hey there,
1: I corrected the VSync enable/disable implementation as requestet in my previous pull request that I closed because I screwed up my form here

2: Setting IsFixedTimeStep to false had no effect. I debugged a lot to day and found out that OpenTK has its own fixedTimeStep logic that was used by MonoGame, while implementing a second FixedTimeStep algorithm in Tick(). I disabled OpenTKs fixedTimeStep as the one provided by MonoGame seems to work _much_ better. This also partly fixes the performance problems I've reported a few days ago.
It brings my whole game back to 60FPS with fixedTimeStep enabled and up to 3k FPS with fixedTimeStep and VSync disabled (in the menu). There are still some performance problems left, but now the game at least doesn't feel so sluggish and slow on high-end hardware any more.

EDIT:
If you are interested, I did some benchmarks of MonoGame vs. XNA without FixedTimeStep and VSync.
Results:
A value of X/Y means, that for my game, I got X FPS in the main menu and Y FPS on average in the game itsself (3D).

On my Netbook with an AMD Fusion E-450 APU, it looked like this:
Windows XNA:                                     340/116
Windows MonoGame:                           310/60
Linux MonoGame with Unity2D desktop: 55/30
Linux MonoGame with XFCE4 desktop:  60/43

On my Desktop with an i7 2600K and an Nvidia  GTX 570
Windows XNA:                                  5300/470
Windows MonoGame:                        4450/550
Linux MonoGame with Unity desktop:  4300/250
Linux MonoGame with XFCE desktop: 5130/370

For the Linux benchmarks, the proprietary binary drivers were used.

EDIT2:
For the Windows benchmarks, I did not recompile on winows but used the Linux-compiled version as I couldn't get MonoDevelop to run on Windows (well, diddn't really try, but it diddn't work out of the box). So the results might be a bit different from real-world results.

data.body:
Hello!

My sprite is located in the directory "textures\texture.png"

The method of finding the expansion (Class: ContentTypeReader, Method Normalize (string fileName, string[] extensions)
receives filename ="textures//texture.png"

Method  MetroHelper.AppDataFileExists always return false, although the expansion of png (I have tried other ) is included in the array "extensions".

This problem is a separator? In the Content.Load method I am passing a string @"textures\textures"
btw, problem in metro app ( branch develop3d)

data.title: Allow setting Vsync for Windows and Linux
data.body:
Hope it doesn't break anything. Since setting VSync is platform dependent, I added a property in GamePlatform so the #ifs are not all over the place.
Sadly I couldn't test if it really works correctly because since the (already reported) performance regression I can't event get to 60 fps. However, the value is correctly forwarded to OpenTK.

data.title: iOS Render to Texture produces black screen - Develop3d Branch
RenderTarget2D doesn't know IsContentLost
data.body:
OS: Linux
I have a dynamic texture in my Game that needs to be rerendert on Windows when the Window-size changes.
The RenderTarget2D has an IsContentLost property that tells me when I have to rerender.
The MonoGame implementation does not have that property.
Contents do not seem to get lost in MonoGame, but the property should be there anyway, because as it is now, code changes need to be done in order to compile with MonoGame.

data.title: Render to texture: RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents ignored

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Hey,
OS: Linux
I do not exactly know how this feature works, but in many tutorials, the following can be found.
1:  React to the this event in your Game class:
OnPreparingDeviceSettings(Object sender, PreparingDeviceSettingsEventArgs e)
by doing this in the constructor:
mGraphicsDeviceManager.PreparingDeviceSettings += OnPreparingDeviceSettings;

2: Set e.GraphicsDeviceInformation.PresentationParameters.RenderTargetUsage = RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents;

When you now change the render target with RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents as the last parameter, the contents of the old render target will not be lost. This allows for render-to-texture code between other rendering-code without getting a purple screen.
MonoGame does not even call OnPreparingDeviceSettings and therefore ignores RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents.

data.title: Sound
data.body:
Real 3D sound attenuation / Doppler calculation using X3dAudio now functional.
Also implemented panning and cleaned up a few other loose ends.

data.title: CHANGE: Regress AndroidGameWindow.SetOrientation to 2.5
MonoGame 3D : GraphicsDevice.PreferedFilter not used so not antialiasing of images.
data.body:
There is no antialiasing used in MonoGame 3D. I set the PreferedFilter and set the XNA game to prefer multi sampling, yet a search through the code reveals that GraphicsDevice.PreferedFilter is not used.

As a result, our images are grainy around their boundaries where we have transparency.

data.title: FIX: Static Window Size on Android
OpenGL Texture Load Performance
data.body:
This pull fixes really bad performance of the Texture2D constructor on all OpenGL platforms, but most noticeable on iOS and Android.  

In our game this improved our loading time from over 40 seconds to under 8 seconds.

The problem was that in the constructor the code was trying to auto generate mipmaps...  which makes no sense.  First off all there is no data in the texture yet, so the auto generation is pointless.  Second XNA Texture2D doesn't support automatic mipmap generation in the first place.

If you have an iOS or Android title with lots of texture content loading you should see a massive improvement in load times.

data.title: Force build to use UTF-8 locale
data.body: otherwise build fails when it encounters UTF-8 characters in source, when building on a non-UTF-8 locale.

data.title: Merge for 2.5.1 Release, from develop
data.body:
updated android to use enumerations rather than hardocded ids as part of the Mono for Android 4.2 update
changed the Android video player to make use of the ViewView. 
corrected namespaces for SongReader and SoundEffectReader
Updated the Keyboard mapping for android
Added RectangleArrayReader
Remvoed links to the third party GamePadBridge.
Added some missing mouseState operators
Replaced all calls to DateTime.Now with DateTime.UtcNow
Fixed SpriteFont rendering (again)
Added code to correclty dispose of Textures on all platforms
Added some fixes for the sound on iOS
Adding missing MediaQueue class
fixed Rectangle Intersect code 
Changed the way UserPrimitives work on windows
Made sure the @2x file support on iOS works
Updated project templates
added project templates for Mac
Fixed MonoDevelop.MonoGame AddIn so it works on Linux
